\textbf{Theorem:} Let $U$ and $V$ be finite-dimensional vector spaces. Then $U^\ast\otimes V^\ast\approx (V\otimes U)^\ast$, given by the isomorphism $(f\otimes g)(u\otimes v)=f(v)g(u)$.
  choice: Let $U$ and $V$ be finite-dimensional vector spaces. Then $U^\ast\otimes V^\ast\approx (V\otimes U)^\ast$, given by the isomorphism $(f\otimes g)(u\otimes v)=f(v)g(u)$.
  choice: Let $U$ and $V$ be vector spaces. Then $U^\ast\otimes V^\ast\approx (U\times V)^\ast$, given by the isomorphism $(f\otimes g)(u\otimes v)=f(u)g(v)$.
  choice: Let $U$ and $V$ be finite-dimensional vector spaces. Then $U^\ast\otimes V^\ast\approx (U\otimes V)^\ast$, given by the isomorphism $(f\otimes g)(u\otimes v)=f(u)g(v)$.
  choice: Let $U$ and $V$ be finite-dimensional vector spaces. Then $U^\ast\times V^\ast\approx (U\otimes V)^\ast$, given by the isomorphism $(f\times g)(u\times v)=f(u)\times g(v)$.

\textbf{Corrected Theorem:}
targets: Let $G$ be a locally compact abelian group and let $\widehat{G}:=Hom(G,\mathbb{T})$ be its Pontryagin dual. There is a canonnical isomorphism between $G$ and $\widehat{\widehat{G}}$.
multiple_choice_targets: Let $f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ be $k$-times differentiable at a point $c$. Then there exists a function $R_f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ such that $$f(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{f''(a)}{2!}(x-a)^2+\cdots+\frac{f^{(k)}}{k!}(x-a)^k + R_f(x)(x-a)^k$$ and $\lim_{x\to a} R_f(a)=0$.

Let $f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ be $k$-times differentiable at a point $c$. Then there exists a function $R_f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ such that $$f(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{f''(a)}{2!}(x-a)^2+\cdots+\frac{f^{(k)}}{k!}(x-a)^k + R_f(x)(x-a)^{k+1}$$ and $\lim_{x\to a} R_f(a)=0$.

Let $f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ be $k$-times differentiable at a point $c$. Then there exists a function $R_f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ such that $$f(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{f''(a)}{2!}(x-a)^2+\cdots+\frac{f^{(k-1)}}{(k-1)!}(x-a)^{k-1} + R_f(x)(x-a)^k$$ and $\lim_{x\to a} R_f(a)=0$.

Let $f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ be $k$-times differentiable at a point $c$. Then there exists a function $R_f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ such that $$f(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{f''(a)}{2!}(x-a)^2+\cdots+\frac{f^{(k)}}{k!}(x-a)^k + \frac{1}{(k+1)!}R_f(x)(x-a)^{k+1}$$ and $\lim_{x\to a} R_f(a)=0$.

\textbf{Theorem:} Let $A$ be a real square matrix such that $A^T=A$. Then there exist $q_i$ such that $Aq_i=\lambda_iq_i$, $\langle q_i,q_j\rangle = 0$ (if $i\neq j$), and $A=Q\Lambda Q^T$.

\textbf{Theorem:} Let $f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ be $k$-times differentiable at a point $c$. Then there exists a function $R_f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ such that $$f(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{f''(a)}{2!}(x-a)^2+\cdots+\frac{f^{(k)}}{k!}(x-a)^k + R_f(x)(x-a)^k$$ and $\lim_{x\to a} R_f(a)=0$.
  choice: Let $f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ be $k$-times differentiable at a point $c$. Then there exists a function $R_f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ such that $$f(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{f''(a)}{2!}(x-a)^2+\cdots+\frac{f^{(k)}}{k!}(x-a)^k + R_f(x)(x-a)^{k+1}$$ and $\lim_{x\to a} R_f(a)=0$.
  choice: Let $f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ be $k$-times differentiable at a point $c$. Then there exists a function $R_f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ such that $$f(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{f''(a)}{2!}(x-a)^2+\cdots+\frac{f^{(k-1)}}{(k-1)!}(x-a)^{k-1} + R_f(x)(x-a)^k$$ and $\lim_{x\to a} R_f(a)=0$.
  choice: Let $f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ be $k$-times differentiable at a point $c$. Then there exists a function $R_f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ such that $$f(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{f''(a)}{2!}(x-a)^2+\cdots+\frac{f^{(k)}}{k!}(x-a)^k + R_f(x)(x-a)^k$$ and $\lim_{x\to a} R_f(a)=0$.
  choice: Let $f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ be $k$-times differentiable at a point $c$. Then there exists a function $R_f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ such that $$f(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{f''(a)}{2!}(x-a)^2+\cdots+\frac{f^{(k)}}{k!}(x-a)^k + \frac{1}{(k+1)!}R_f(x)(x-a)^{k+1}$$ and $\lim_{x\to a} R_f(a)=0$.
